Instrument.name: Galileo Dust Detection System for GO
Instrument.description: The Galileo dust experiment employs a specialized hemispherical sensor constructed from 0.1 mm thick gold foil, equipped with precision grids and advanced detection systems, to study micro-dust particles within the Jovian environment. This instrument seeks to elucidate the physical and dynamical characteristics of particles ranging from 10^-16 to 10^-6 grams, focusing on key parameters including mass, velocity, charge, and trajectory. The experiment's specific objectives include examining the interactions between the Galilean moons and their surrounding dust environments, assessing the influence of magnetospheric plasma and Jovian magnetic fields on particle dynamics, and probing gravitational impacts on interplanetary dust. The detection mechanism harnesses charge induction from incoming particles, supplemented by sophisticated amplifiers and detectors—such as a channeltron—which operates effectively amidst electrical noise. Calibration efforts conducted at the Heidelberg dust accelerator have laid the groundwork for establishing reliable measurements of particle speed and mass, revealing intricate relationships between charge yields and environmental factors. Additionally, the instrument's onboard processing capabilities facilitate advanced noise discrimination to ensure a high fidelity of detected impacts over the course of the mission. Positioned strategically on the spinning Galileo spacecraft, this research instrument promises to expand our understanding of dust phenomena in the vicinity of Jupiter and its satellites.
